Abortion policy should be guided by principles most people share: minimizing preventable suffering, protecting health, and valuing responsibility and care for children and families. Even across deep moral disagreement, there is room to unite around fewer unintended pregnancies, better maternal healthcare, and stronger social supports. Grounding law in these practical, humane goals can bridge divides without erasing differences.

Laws on abortion should be guided not by slogans but by a careful weighing of competing goods—life, liberty, health, and fairness—along with humility about complex cases. People who disagree sharply can still endorse policies that reduce abortions through support, not coercion: contraception, education, and economic help for families. A bridge is focusing on shared responsibilities to protect vulnerable people, whatever one’s starting moral framework.
